title.value: INTREPPPID - An Orthologue-Informed Quintuplet Network for Cross-Species Prediction of Protein-Protein Interaction
title.justification: This title accurately reflects the content and focus of the paper, which introduces the INTREPPPID model for cross-species protein-protein interaction prediction using a quintuplet network informed by orthologues.
title.quote:
MANUSCRIPT TITLE
INTREPPPID - An Orthologue-Informed Quintuplet Network for Cross-Species Prediction of Protein-Protein Interaction

extractions.description: The paper introduces INTREPPPID, a deep learning model designed to enhance cross-species prediction of protein-protein interactions (PPI) by integrating orthology data and a quintuplet network architecture. This approach is aimed at improving PPI inference across different species by employing an innovative architecture and leveraging orthologue data. The study also presents a web server and software tool to facilitate the use of INTREPPPID by the broader community.

type.justification: The paper describes experiments, evaluations, and comparisons of the INTREPPPID model with other models, and shows empirical results regarding its performance on PPI tasks.
type.quote: INTREPPPID outperforms all other leading PPI inference methods tested on both the intra-species and cross-species tasks using strict evaluation datasets.

name.justification: The paper focuses on computational methods for predicting protein-protein interactions, which is a key aspect of bioinformatics.
name.quote: INTREPPPID is a deep learning model for inferring the interaction of two proteins given their amino acid sequences.

name.justification: The paper specifically addresses the prediction of protein-protein interactions using computational methods.
name.quote: We present INTREPPPID, a method which incorporates orthology data using a new “quintuplet” neural network, which is constructed with five parallel encoders with shared parameters.

name.justification: The paper introduces and extensively evaluates the INTREPPPID model for protein-protein interaction prediction.
name.quote: Here, we introduce an extension of RAPPPID named INTREPPPID (Incorporating Triplet Error for Predicting PPIs using Deep Learning).

is_contributed.justification: INTREPPPID is a new model introduced by the authors as part of this study.
is_contributed.quote: Here, we introduce an extension of RAPPPID named INTREPPPID.

is_executed.justification: The model is executed and its performance is evaluated on PPI tasks.
is_executed.quote: INTREPPPID outperforms all other leading PPI inference methods tested on both the intra-species and cross-species tasks.

is_compared.justification: INTREPPPID is compared against several leading PPI prediction methods.
is_compared.quote: INTREPPPID performed slightly better than RAPPPID across all metrics, and outperformed all other methods.

referenced_paper_title.value: RAPPPID: Towards generalizable protein interaction prediction with AWD-LSTM twin networks
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references RAPPPID as the prior work upon which INTREPPPID is based.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Here, we introduce an extension of RAPPPID named INTREPPPID.

name.justification: RAPPPID is mentioned as a precursor to the proposed INTREPPPID model and is used as a benchmark for comparison.
name.quote: RAPPPID, our previous method upon which INTREPPPID expands.

is_contributed.justification: RAPPPID is not introduced in this paper but is referenced as prior work.
is_contributed.quote: RAPPPID, our previous method upon which INTREPPPID expands.

is_executed.justification: RAPPPID is executed and used for comparative evaluation in the paper.
is_executed.quote: INTREPPPID performed slightly better than RAPPPID across all metrics, and outperformed all other methods.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares the performance of INTREPPPID with RAPPPID.
is_compared.quote: INTREPPPID performed slightly better than RAPPPID across all metrics, and outperformed all other methods.

referenced_paper_title.value: RAPPPID: Towards generalizable protein interaction prediction with AWD-LSTM twin networks
referenced_paper_title.justification: The text references RAPPPID as a preparatory work for their own research.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Here, we introduce an extension of RAPPPID named INTREPPPID.

name.justification: STRING is used as a source of PPI data for creating datasets for training and evaluation in this study.
name.quote: We selected the STRING database as the source of PPIs for our datasets as it is large, contains information for many species, and integrates confidence scores from a number of modalities.

referenced_paper_title.value: The STRING database in 2023: Protein–protein association networks and functional enrichment analyses for any sequenced genome of interest
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references STRING as the source of data for generating PPI datasets.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We selected the STRING database as the source of PPIs for our datasets.

name.justification: The OMA database is referenced as a source of orthology data for training the model.
name.quote: All orthology data for the experiments conducted herein are from the OMA database of orthologues.

referenced_paper_title.value: OMA orthology in 2021: Website overhaul, conserved isoforms, ancestral gene order and more
referenced_paper_title.justification: OMA is identified as the source of orthologue data in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: All orthology data for the experiments conducted herein are from the OMA database of orthologues.

name.justification: SentencePiece is utilized for tokenizing sequences in the INTREPPPID model.
name.quote: Before encoding, sequences are first tokenized using the Unigram algorithm as implemented by the SentencePiece library.

referenced_paper_title.value: SentencePiece: A simple and language independent subword tokenizer and detokenizer for neural text processing
referenced_paper_title.justification: SentencePiece is cited in the context of tokenizing sequences for the model.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Before encoding, sequences are first tokenized using the Unigram algorithm as implemented by the SentencePiece library.
